content.raw:
I kind of thought that would be the case :).  Thanks for the pointers.  I have some questions on how we go about doing this:

- For Homebrew, I think I've made the appropriate changes for the formula.  I'll open a [PR](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/345) for this.
- For Windows, I added new deps to release-tools, but it looks like Windows builds try to go and download zip files from http://packages.osrfoundation.org/win32/deps/ .  However, there does not seem to be a zip file for ignition-cmake there, which begs the question of how this is working for ignition-common, ignition-math4, etc.  Any thoughts?
- The Xenial stuff is pretty straightforward, though I wonder if it has to be backwards compatible.  That is, if I change the release scripts to depend on libignition-cmake-dev and libignition-math4-dev, do I need to worry about building older versions of ignition-rndf?

content.raw:
* For Homebrew, I think @scpeters can give you better guidance on that PR
* For Windows, I'd try copying what is done on the libs that are building successfully, I think a change from `project-default-devel-windows.bat` to `generic-default-devel-windows.bat` is part of it

Since this is still in version 0, I think there is no need to be backwards compatible, i.e. we won't keep supporting previous zero versions. Actually, this PR probably prompts a bump to 0.2.0.

For testing your changes on Jenkins, you can start a new branch on `release-tools` and use that when you trigger the build.

• For Homebrew, I think @scpeters can give you better guidance on that PR
  • For Windows, I'd try copying what is done on the libs that are building successfully, I think a change from project-default-devel-windows.bat to generic-default-devel-windows.bat is part of it

Since this is still in version 0, I think there is no need to be backwards compatible, i.e. we won't keep supporting previous zero versions. Actually, this PR probably prompts a bump to 0.2.0.

For testing your changes on Jenkins, you can start a new branch on release-tools and use that when you trigger the build.

content.raw: CI is happy now
content.html: CI is happy now

content.raw:
Note that the Windows "failure" is due to build warnings, mostly C4251 which has to do with how we use `std::unique_ptr` for our PIMPL implementation.

Currently we get that warning in almost all of our projects except `ign-math` which doesn't use much PIMPL and `ign-common` which has a highly targeted warning suppression feature.

Ideally, all of our libraries would use the warning suppression feature of `ign-common`, but that would require making `ign-common` a required dependency of all of our projects, and that's not a very appealing option right now.

I would recommend that for right now we either (1) ignore the warnings, or (2) completely suppress the C4251 warning from cmake.

In the long-term, we should consider the possibility of moving the warning suppression feature of `ign-common` upstream to `ign-cmake` somehow, since all of our libraries would benefit from the warning suppression feature and all of our libraries require `ign-cmake` anyway. The catch is that `ign-cmake` would then become more than just a library of cmake modules.
content.html:
Note that the Windows "failure" is due to build warnings, mostly C4251 which has to do with how we use std::unique_ptr for our PIMPL implementation.

Currently we get that warning in almost all of our projects except ign-math which doesn't use much PIMPL and ign-common which has a highly targeted warning suppression feature.

Ideally, all of our libraries would use the warning suppression feature of ign-common, but that would require making ign-common a required dependency of all of our projects, and that's not a very appealing option right now.

I would recommend that for right now we either (1) ignore the warnings, or (2) completely suppress the C4251 warning from cmake.

In the long-term, we should consider the possibility of moving the warning suppression feature of ign-common upstream to ign-cmake somehow, since all of our libraries would benefit from the warning suppression feature and all of our libraries require ign-cmake anyway. The catch is that ign-cmake would then become more than just a library of cmake modules.

content.raw: Thanks.  I'm going to go ahead and disable C4251 in just ign-rndf for now.
content.html: Thanks. I'm going to go ahead and disable C4251 in just ign-rndf for now.

content.raw: Woohoo!  Blue CI.  This PR grew kind of large, but there is a lot of removal here.  In conjunction with https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/503, I think this is ready to be reviewed.
content.html: Woohoo! Blue CI. This PR grew kind of large, but there is a lot of removal here. In conjunction with https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/503, I think this is ready to be reviewed.

content.raw:
I suppose the damage is already done, but it would be easier to suppress these warnings using `target_compile_options(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} PRIVATE "/wd4251")`. The `/wd4251` compile option is documented [here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/thxezb7y.aspx).

That way, we wouldn't need to put the pragma statements in all the headers and then remove them later when we have a more targeted solution.
content.html:
I suppose the damage is already done, but it would be easier to suppress these warnings using target_compile_options(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} PRIVATE "/wd4251"). The /wd4251 compile option is documented here.

That way, we wouldn't need to put the pragma statements in all the headers and then remove them later when we have a more targeted solution.

content.raw: I was aiming to go more for the ign-common route, where it is targeted where we need it (which is everywhere, I guess).  If you prefer just the compile option, I could also do that; I don't feel too strongly either way.
content.html: I was aiming to go more for the ign-common route, where it is targeted where we need it (which is everywhere, I guess). If you prefer just the compile option, I could also do that; I don't feel too strongly either way.

content.raw:
In `ign-common`, we're super-targeting the suppression using the `IGN_COMMON_WARN_IGNORE__DLL_INTERFACE_MISSING` and `IGN_COMMON_WARN_RESUME__DLL_INTERFACE_MISSING` macros. Only the exact line that contains the PIMPL pointer gets the warning suppression. That's the ideal fix for this warning.

The current approach in this branch, where we wrap the entire header in the warning suppression, is effectively the same as just using the `target_compile_options(...)` approach, because the warning can only ever apply to classes that are in those headers. To get this branch as targeted as `ign-common`, we would need to put those `#ifdef` blocks directly around the PIMPL pointer line (or else reimplement a simpler version of the suppression macros that are defined in `ign-common`).

Whenever possible, I prefer to not have gross `#ifdef <PLATFORM>` statements in the public-facing headers, because I don't want users to have to see those, so I'd suggest using the `target_compile_options(~)` approach instead.
content.html:
In ign-common, we're super-targeting the suppression using the IGN_COMMON_WARN_IGNORE__DLL_INTERFACE_MISSING and IGN_COMMON_WARN_RESUME__DLL_INTERFACE_MISSING macros. Only the exact line that contains the PIMPL pointer gets the warning suppression. That's the ideal fix for this warning.

The current approach in this branch, where we wrap the entire header in the warning suppression, is effectively the same as just using the target_compile_options(...) approach, because the warning can only ever apply to classes that are in those headers. To get this branch as targeted as ign-common, we would need to put those #ifdef blocks directly around the PIMPL pointer line (or else reimplement a simpler version of the suppression macros that are defined in ign-common).

Whenever possible, I prefer to not have gross #ifdef <PLATFORM> statements in the public-facing headers, because I don't want users to have to see those, so I'd suggest using the target_compile_options(~) approach instead.

content.raw: I remember some recent discussions in favour of more targeted suppression of these warnings on sdformat.
content.html: I remember some recent discussions in favour of more targeted suppression of these warnings on sdformat.

content.raw:
The only way to get more targeted is to recreate what `ign-common` is doing. Ideally that highly-targeted warning suppression utility should be moved upstream to a base dependency that every library uses (like what `ign-cmake` currently is).

I've mentioned this before, with the suggestion that we rename `ign-cmake` to something like `ign-utils` or `ign-base` and merge in the most basic utilities of `ign-common`. I should open an issue about this somewhere so I have something to easily reference.
content.html:
The only way to get more targeted is to recreate what ign-common is doing. Ideally that highly-targeted warning suppression utility should be moved upstream to a base dependency that every library uses (like what ign-cmake currently is).

I've mentioned this before, with the suggestion that we rename ign-cmake to something like ign-utils or ign-base and merge in the most basic utilities of ign-common. I should open an issue about this somewhere so I have something to easily reference.

content.raw:
Right, that's effectively the same as what `ign-common` is doing, just not as succinctly.

I'm not a fan of that because I think users (who have no need to be concerned about the ugliness of how symbols are exported on Windows) may find that block of preprocessor directives alarming and distracting. I won't contest it as a temporary solution to this issue, but I think we should very seriously consider how to make the cross-platform warning suppression feature available to all of our libraries.

Edit: I mean we should consider it for future development, not for our current code freeze schedule.
content.html:
Right, that's effectively the same as what ign-common is doing, just not as succinctly.

I'm not a fan of that because I think users (who have no need to be concerned about the ugliness of how symbols are exported on Windows) may find that block of preprocessor directives alarming and distracting. I won't contest it as a temporary solution to this issue, but I think we should very seriously consider how to make the cross-platform warning suppression feature available to all of our libraries.

Edit: I mean we should consider it for future development, not for our current code freeze schedule.

content.raw:
Agreed for future development, we should think about something nicer.  I also realized that we really have to have the suppressions in the file, rather than a command-line argument.  While a command-line argument would allow *this* project to compile without warnings, it would not suppress the warnings for any outside project that depended on this library.

In any case, I've now gone ahead and made the suppressions more targeted, like ign-common.
content.html:
Agreed for future development, we should think about something nicer. I also realized that we really have to have the suppressions in the file, rather than a command-line argument. While a command-line argument would allow this project to compile without warnings, it would not suppress the warnings for any outside project that depended on this library.

In any case, I've now gone ahead and made the suppressions more targeted, like ign-common.

content.raw:
The warning shouldn't get emitted for consumers of the project, because the `IGNITION_RNDF_VISIBLE` macro will collapse to `__declspec(dllimport)` when it's used by consumer libraries/applications, and therefore Visual Studio will not care that the dll-interface is missing for the PIMPL pointer and should not emit a warning about it.

That's why I suggested making it a `PRIVATE` compile option instead of `PUBLIC` compile option.
content.html:
The warning shouldn't get emitted for consumers of the project, because the IGNITION_RNDF_VISIBLE macro will collapse to __declspec(dllimport) when it's used by consumer libraries/applications, and therefore Visual Studio will not care that the dll-interface is missing for the PIMPL pointer and should not emit a warning about it.

That's why I suggested making it a PRIVATE compile option instead of PUBLIC compile option.

content.html: To be clear, the current solution is perfectly fine, just not very pleasant to look at.

content.html: For now, I'm fine targeting just the lines that cause problems in this library. I'll go ahead and do that.

content.raw:
I realize that this was based off of an example, but we don't actually ever need to use the `ign_target_interface_include_directories` macro. I was making a mistake when I created this macro. I need to remember to remove it from `ign-common`. I suggest we take it out here as well.

It's not harmful, but it's also not accomplishing anything.

It's not harmful, but it's also not accomplishing anything.

content.raw: This shouldn't be necessary. Since the main library publicly depends on `ign-math4`, the standard features requirement will get inherited by `ign-rndf0`, and then inherited by its tests as well.
content.html: This shouldn't be necessary. Since the main library publicly depends on ign-math4, the standard features requirement will get inherited by ign-rndf0, and then inherited by its tests as well.

content.raw: I don't think this should be necessary, unless we're generating a library for the tests in the `test` directory. And if that *is* the case, then we should be linking the target of that library to the targets of the tests instead of using `link_directories(~)`.
content.html: I don't think this should be necessary, unless we're generating a library for the tests in the test directory. And if that is the case, then we should be linking the target of that library to the targets of the tests instead of using link_directories(~).

content.raw:
It just occurred to me: `${DL_TARGET}` doesn't belong in here. It's an `ign-common` dependency that provides `dlopen` and `dlclose`, but `ign-rndf` doesn't use those.

This variable will collapse into nothing since the cmake script never calls `find_package(DL)`, so it won't have any effect (positively or negatively), but we should still remove this to avoid confusion.
content.html:
It just occurred to me: ${DL_TARGET} doesn't belong in here. It's an ign-common dependency that provides dlopen and dlclose, but ign-rndf doesn't use those.

This variable will collapse into nothing since the cmake script never calls find_package(DL), so it won't have any effect (positively or negatively), but we should still remove this to avoid confusion.

content.raw: it looks like this function is being removed from the API; is that intentional?
content.html: it looks like this function is being removed from the API; is that intentional?

content.raw: I didn't make the decision to remove it, but I think it makes sense to do so. `ign-rndf` isn't a library for manipulating environment variables, so it would be more appropriate for this to be an internal function than something that we export as part of the `ign-rndf` API.
content.html: I didn't make the decision to remove it, but I think it makes sense to do so. ign-rndf isn't a library for manipulating environment variables, so it would be more appropriate for this to be an internal function than something that we export as part of the ign-rndf API.

content.raw: Yeah, it is intentional.  I was running into some problems with cppcheck, and while investigating, I found that this wasn't being used anymore, so I removed it.  Now that you mention it, it is part of the public API, so maybe I shouldn't remove it.  What do you think?
content.html: Yeah, it is intentional. I was running into some problems with cppcheck, and while investigating, I found that this wasn't being used anymore, so I removed it. Now that you mention it, it is part of the public API, so maybe I shouldn't remove it. What do you think?

content.raw: I'd say remove it. If someone is relying on an RNDF library for the sake of retrieving environment variables, then they're making some pretty questionable decisions in the first place.
content.html: I'd say remove it. If someone is relying on an RNDF library for the sake of retrieving environment variables, then they're making some pretty questionable decisions in the first place.

content.raw:
I say remove it

I just wanted to make sure it was intentional
